conclusion: Determine the work done by the gas on the surroundings from state D to state A.
The process from D to A is a constant pressure process (isobaric).
The formula for work done during an isobaric process is W = P ΔV.
State D has volume V2 and State A has volume V1.
Since the process is isobaric, the pressure P is the same at both states D and A.
Identify the initial volume (V2) and the final volume (V1).
Calculate the change in volume ΔV: ΔV = V1 - V2.
Use the formula for work done during an isobaric process: W = P ΔV.
Substitute the values: W = P (V1 - V2).
The work done by the gas on the surroundings when transitioning from state D to state A is P (V1 - V2).
